Activity enhancement of ceria-supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts by tuning reducibility and metal enrichment Biyun Fang Zeliang Qi Fangming Liu Chuanfeng Zhang Chunyan Li Jun Ni Jianxin Lin Bingyu Lin ⁎ Lilong Jiang ⁎ National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst, College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst College of Chemical Engineering Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350002 Fujian China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst, College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The development of efficient oxides-supported bimetallic catalysts is critical for ammonia synthesis or other catalytic reactions. Herein, the design of ceria-supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts with different properties is performed by changing Mo addition to enhance the ammonia synthesis activities. It is found that the reduction of ceria and molybdenum oxide would be boosted by Co species, but the reduction of the bimetallic catalyst would be inhibited by the aggregated molybdenum oxide for the catalyst with Co and Mo simultaneous addition. On the contrary, this ill effect of molybdenum oxide on the reduction of the bimetallic catalyst can be effectively alleviated by the subsequent addition of Mo species to ceria-supported Co catalyst, resulting in enhancement of the proportion of Co metal, Ce3+ and low-valent Mo species, as well as surface enrichment of Co species. In such cases, the amount of the adsorbed hydrogen and nitrogen species would increase, and hydrogen species preferentially desorbs following a pathway of H2 formation. As a result, the catalyst obtained by the separate addition of Co and Mo shows 2.5-fold more active than its counterpart with the simultaneous addition of Co and Mo species. These findings provide a valuable insight in designing reducible oxide-supported bimetallic catalysts in ammonia synthesis or other hydrogen-involved reactions. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Bimetallic catalyst Ceria Hydrogen adsorption–desorption Synergistic effect 1 Introduction Bimetallic catalysts usually show superior catalytic performances to the monometallic counterparts owing to the synergistic effects between two catalytically active metals in geometric, electronic, or other properties [1,2]. In this respect, various bimetallic catalysts have attracted enormous attention due to multifunctional applications in diverse areas, and the Co-Mo system has been studiedextensively. For instance, Sun et al. found that there is a combination of high activity of cobalt nitride and high stability of molybdenum nitride in the alloyed Co–Mo nitrides, leading to enhancement of the oxygen reduction reaction activity [3]. Yu and co-workers demonstrated that the catalytic performances of hydrogen evolution reaction and urea oxidation reaction would be boosted as a result of the synergistic functionalities of Co–Mo bimetallic centers for the Co2Mo3O8 catalysts [4]. Huang et al. proposed that the surface Mo sites in Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts can stabilize the HO* intermediates, while the Co sites can stabilize HOO* intermediates. This synergetic effect of Co and Mo sites results in enhancement of oxygen evolution reaction activity [5]. In these applications, the synergy between Co and Mo species plays a crucial role in the improvement of catalytic performances. The reaction of ammonia synthesis, which is a vital reaction process in the production of chemical fertilizers, has gained a widespread attention. Currently, the typical large-scale and centralized Haber-Bosch process, which used fossil fuels (e.g. methane) as fuel and feedstock, are mainly carried out under high temperatures and pressures (400–500 °C, 20–30 MPa) with Fe catalyst [6,7], leading to the 1–2% of the global energy consumption and 1.5% of the CO2 emission [8,9]. With the extensive application of ammonia in renewable energy, including of as a hydrogen storage carrier or the generation of power [9-12], more and more researchers have committed to develop the high efficiency ammonia synthesis under the mild conditions. The application of Ru catalyst can substantially reduce the energy consumption due to its mild reaction condition (∼100 bar) [13,14]. However, the high cost of Ru catalyst limits the widely use of ruthenium-based catalysts. Therefore, the development of inexpensive non-precious metal ammonia synthesis catalysts is urgently needed. The dissociation of N2 and H2 molecules, the reaction of adsorbed H and N species and the desorption of ammonia or other unreacted gases (N2 and H2) are the main steps of ammonia synthesis reaction [15,16]. Among them the dissociation of N2, which required high activation barrier, is usually suggested to the rate-limiting step. On the other hand, the optimum active species for ammonia synthesis is that bond nitrogen molecules/atoms with an intermediate strength because there are scaling relations to achieve high ammonia synthesis activities for various active metals [17,18]. As a result, there is a volcano-shaped relation between the ammonia synthesis activity and the nitrogen adsorption energy of various metal catalysts. Ternary nitride Co3Mo3N consisted of Co and Mo, which adsorb nitrogen too weakly and strongly, would exhibit a middle N-bonding energy, leading to higher catalytic activity than commercial Fe catalysts under high ammonia concentration [19-21]. Recently, the efficient ceria-supported cobalt-molybdenum bimetallic catalysts, which have adjustable N-bonding energy with the change of metal ratio, also have been prepared by NaNaph-liquid-phase reduction [22,23]. These results confirm that tuning nitrogen activation using bimetal catalysts can unlock superior ammonia synthesis activities. Besides nitrogen activation, the tuning of hydrogen adsorption–desorption property or other approaches also can be adopted to enhance the ammonia synthesis activity of a catalyst. For example, Wu et al. found that the use of polar MgO(111) as the support contributed to the hydrogen removal for Ru catalysts, leading to alleviation of hydrogen poisoning as well as enhancement of ammonia synthesis activity [24]. Lin et al. proposed that the difference in the alumina phase affected the hydrogen poisoning and ammonia synthesis performances for alumina-supported Ru catalysts owing to the change in the hydrogen adsorption/desorption property [25]. On the other hand, due to the unique Ce3+/Ce4+ redox ability, electronic property and hydrogen adsorption property of ceria, CeO2-supported metal catalysts have been widely applied in ammonia synthesis or other catalytic reactions. In the meantime, the difference in the reduction degree of ceria or the metal–support interaction effects between ceria and active metals would strongly affects the catalytic performances of ceria-supported metal catalysts [26-28]. As a result, it can be expected that the performances of ceria-supported bimetallic catalysts can be tuned by changing the reduction degree of ceria or the metal–support interaction effect. In this work, we attempt to tune the metal dispersion and the reduction degree of ceria and metals as well as the metal-support interactions of ceria-supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts to enhance the catalytic activity in the ammonia synthesis. The results show that due to enhancement of surface enrichment of Co and Mo species, proportions of the low-valent Mo species and metallic Co and ceria reducibility, as well as the improvement in the hydrogen adsorption–desorption properties, the catalyst with separately added Co and Mo shows more than 2.5-fold higher activity than that with the simultaneous addition of Co and Mo species in ammonia synthesis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation CoMo/CeO2 was prepared by co-precipitation method. Cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Aladdin-chemistry Co., >99%), cobalt nitrate ((Co(NO3)3·6H2O, Aladdin-chemistry Co., >99%) and ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Sinopharm chemical Co., >99%) were used as Ce, Co and Mo precursors. Typically, 25.2 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in deionized water (20 mL). 2 g Co(NO3)3·6H2O and 1.1 g (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were dispersed into the above cerium nitrate solution under stirring. Afterward, 140 mL of NH3·H2O (Sinopharm chemical Co., 28%) was added drop by drop into above mixture solution at room temperature. After continuously stirring for 2.5 h, the suspension was filtered and washed with ethanol for three times. Then, the resulting precipitate was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h and heated at 600 °C for 6 h. Finally, the as-obtained sample was reduced in N2-H2 mixture at 500 °C for 6 h, and then passivated in a 0.5 % O2/Ar gas mixture at room temperature to obtained CoMo/CeO2 catalyst. Mo/CeO2 and Co/CeO2 were prepared in the same way. The unreduced Co/CeO2 powder was impregnated with ammonium molybdate solution containing 1.1 g (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, and then as-obtained sample was reduced and passivated to obtain the final Mo/Co-CeO2 catalyst. The schematic illustration for the synthesis of catalysts is shown in Fig. S1 and the actual amount of Co and Mo in catalysts determined by ICP-AES analysis. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The texture properties of the samples were measured by Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus at − 196 °C. The structures of the samples were analyzed by XRD analysis in a PANalytical X’Pert3 powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Raman spectra was recorded by an InVia Reflex Raman microscope. The structures and the morphology were characterized using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 microscope operated at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were acquired using an ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer. The measurements were carried out for the samples without treatment to obtain the XPS spectra of the as-prepared samples. Samples were reduced at 500 °C for 6 h in 75 %H2/25 %N2 mixture in a pretreatment chamber attached to the spectrometer, then the measurements were performed to collect the XPS spectra of the the-reduced catalysts. Elemental composition depth profiles of the samples were obtained by a sequence of 30 s and 60 s Ar+ ion etching (2 keV) followed by XPS measurements. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD), Temperature-programmed desorption of nitrogen (N2-TPD), D/H exchange reaction, and Temperature-programmed surface reaction were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. For H2-TPR, 100 mg of catalyst was purged in Ar at 150 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. Afterward, the sample was heated from 50 °C to 600 °C in 10% H2/Ar mixture. For H2-TPD and N2-TPD experiments, the catalyst was reduced in H2 at 500 °C for 6 h and then cooled to 400 °C in Ar. Afterwards, hydrogen or nitrogen was introduced to sample for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. Finally, the sample was heated in Ar flow to 600 °C, and the mass signals of H2 (m/z = 2) and N (m/z = 14) were obtained. For D/H exchange reaction, the reduced sample adsorbed D2 at 400 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. After purging by Ar for 1 h, the 3.3 %N2 − 10 %H2 − Ar mixed gas was introduced and the mass signals were obtained. For TPSR study, the sample adsorbed D2, or N2 at 400 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. Finally, the sample was heated to 900 °C in 3.3 %N2 − 10 %H2 − Ar gas mixture or 10 %H2 − Ar gas mixture, and the signal of NH (m/z = 15) was recorded. 2.3 Ammonia synthesis measurement The obtained catalysts were reduced in 75 %H2 − 25 %N2 gas mixture at 500 °C for 6 h. Afterward, the ammonia in the outlet gas was collected for three times by sulfuric acid solution (0.02 mol L-1) under the designated temperature, pressure and gas flow rate. In the absence of mass transport and heat transfer effects (See supplementary information), the concentration of ammonium ion was determined by ion chromatography (ICS-600, Thermo Scientific) and then the ammonia synthesis rate was calculated accordingly. The tests of the catalysts were repeated for more than 3 times to ensure reproducibility, and the error range was ± 5%. To measure the reaction orders with respect to N2 and H2, 0.2 g of catalyst was loaded into the reactor and the gas flow rate was fixed at 120 mL min−1. The constituent gases of the reactant (N2, H2, Ar) were as follows in volume fraction (10%, 50%, 40%), (20%, 50%, 30%) and (34%, 50%, 16%) for N2 order, (20%, 30%, 50%), (20%, 50%, 30%) and (20%, 80%, 0) for H2 order. The NH3 order was obtained by changing the flow rate of a stoichiometric H2–N2 gas mixture (60–240 mL min−1). The kinetic experiments were carried out far from equilibrium conditions, and the reaction orders were calculated according to the methods described elsewhere [23,29]. The reaction orders were estimated by using the following Eqs: (1) r = k P N 2 α P H 2 β P N H 3 γ (2) r = 1 W d y 0 d ( 1 q 0 ) (3) m y 0 m - 1 d y 0 = C d ( 1 q 0 ) (4) C = k 2 P N 2 α P H 2 β where r is the ammonia synthesis rate, α, β, and γ are the reaction orders with respect to N2, H2, and NH3, respectively. P N2, P H2, and P NH3 are the partial pressures of N2, H2, and NH3, respectively. And W, y0 and q0 represent the catalyst mass, molar fraction of ammonia in the outlet gas and relationship between flow rate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization As listed in Table S1, the surface area of cerium oxide is 45 m2 g−1, and the presence of Mo leads to the slight decline in the surface area for Mo/CeO2, while the introduction of Co increases the surface area for Co/CeO2 (59 m2 g−1). On the other hand, the surface areas of catalysts containing Mo and Co are close to that of CeO2. As shown in XRD diffraction patterns (Fig. S2), all samples show the diffraction peaks centred at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.6°, 56.4°, 59.2°, 69.5°, 76.8°, 79.2°, 88.6° and 95.6°, which are assigned to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), (422) and (511) planes of the cubic fluoride CeO2 phase (PDF No. 65-5923), indicating that the presence of Co or Mo species has a limited influence on the phase of CeO2. The Co and Mo content, measured by ICP analysis, is 1.31, 5.73 wt% and 1.24, 5.68 wt% for CoMo/CeO2 and Mo/Co-CeO2, respectively (Table S2). However, there are no any diffraction peaks belonging to Mo and Co species, suggesting that Co or Mo species are highly dispersed over the surface of CeO2 [30,31]. As shown in the Raman spectra (Fig. 1 ), all samples present four characteristic peaks at around 250, 460, 587 and 1180 cm−1, which correspond to the 2TA (second-order transverse acoustic mode), F2g (fluorite F2g mode), D (defect-induced mode) and 2LO (second-order longitudinal optical mode) modes of CeO2, respectively (Fig. 1a) [32-38]. The A1g mode band of spinel-type Co3O4 would be found in the spectra of Co/CeO2 (678 cm−1) [39-41], which might be due to Co enrichment onto the surface of catalyst, as evident from the energy dispersive X-ray elemental maps (EDX) (Fig. S3). In the meantime, the broadening of the F2g band can be found for the Co-containing samples, which may be due to the overlapping ofF2gmode of CeO2 and Eg mode of Co3O4.There are no characteristic band of spinel-type Co3O4 at 678 cm−1 in the Raman spectra of CoMo/CeO2 and Mo/Co-CeO2, further confirming that Co species is highly dispersed over CeO2 for the bimetallic catalysts. Besides, the bands of CeO2, there are a distinct band at ca. 947 cm−1 and two other weak bands (808 and 991 cm−1) in the Raman spectrum of Mo/CeO2. The former band is related to the O–Mo–O symmetric stretch associated with surface molybdenum oxide species, and the other bands are attributed to Mo–O–Mo vibration and the terminal Mo=O stretch during tocrystalline MoO3, respectively [38,42,43]. There is an interaction among Co, Mo and Ce species, and thus the band shifts from 947 cm−1 shift to lower wavelength (913 cm−1) for CoMo/CeO2. However, the bands at 808 and 991 cm−1 for Mo/Co-CeO2 weaken, suggesting that most bulk MoO3 would be transformed into surface molybdenum oxide species, which might be due to the spread of Mo atoms over CeO2 surface [42,44,45]. The intensity ratio of the bands at 587 and 1180 cm−1 to 460 cm−1 band reflects oxygen vacancy concentration [33,34,46,47]. The ratios of I(587+1180)/I460 are estimated: Co/CeO2 > Mo/Co-CeO2 > CoMo/CeO2 > CeO2 > Mo/CeO2 (Fig. S4), indicating that the introduction of Co species leads to enhancement of oxygen vacancy, while the presence of Mo species has opposite effect. The differences in the dispersion of Co species and the form of molybdenum oxide species might strongly affect the reduction property of the bimetallic catalysts, thus H2-TPR measurements are performed. As shown in Fig. 2 , there is a high-temperature peak located at 814 °C for all samples, corresponding to the reduction of inner layer CeO2 and bulk oxygen [48]. The peak at 509 °C attributed to the reduction of surface CeO2 is observed in pure CeO2 [34]. The reduction peaks of surface CeO2 and molybdenum oxides would overlap, and thus the maximum hydrogen consumption peak appears at 551 °C for Mo/CeO2 (Fig. 2). On the contrary, the reduction peak of surface CeO2 shifts to low temperature (413 °C) for Co/CeO2, indicating that the presence of Co promotes surface CeO2 reduction [33,49]. Moreover, two reduction peaks ranging from 200 to 350 °C are observed in Co/CeO2 (Fig. 2), which are ascribed to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 [49]. However, no reduction peaks below 300 °C would be found during the H2-TPR studies of CoMo/CeO2, revealing that the reduction of cobalt oxides would be inhibited by the presence of molybdenum oxides. In the meantime, the hydrogen consumptions are similar between Mo/CeO2 and CoMo/CeO2 (Table S1). There are two weak peaks attributed to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 at about 221 and 260 °C for Mo/Co-CeO2, indicating that the subsequent introduction of molybdenum species effectively alleviates the inhibition effect of molybdenum oxides on the reduction of cobalt oxides. The interaction between molybdenum oxides and ceria might be weakened by the existing Co/CeO2 for the sample with pre-addition of Co species (Mo/Co-CeO2). Moreover, the hydrogen activation and the hydrogen spillover would be accelerated by Co species. In this case, the reduction of molybdenum oxides and CeO2 would be boosted for Mo/Co-CeO2, and thus the amount of hydrogen consumption increases greatly (Fig. 2 and Table S1). To evaluate the electronic property of catalysts, the valence states of Co, Mo, Ce, O were investigated by XPS. Only hexavalent molybdenum species and cobalt oxides can be observed in the as-prepared samples (Figs. S5 and S6). However, there are two peaks at 778.0 and 781.0 eV in the Co 2p spectra for the reduced bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 3 a), attributing to metallic Co and CoO, respectively [50-52], indicating that not all cobalt oxides would be reduced into metallic Co for CoMo/CeO2 and Mo/Co-CeO2. As shown in Fig. 3b, the Mo 3d profiles can be deconvoluted into 6 peaks (three pairs of 3d5/2 and 3d3/), the 3d5/2 at 229.8, 231.5 and 232.6 eV are assigned to Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+, respectively [53-55]. Mo/Co-CeO2 shows higher Co/Ce ratio than that of CoMo/CeO2 and Co/CeO2 (Table S3), suggesting that the separate introduction of Co and Mo species enhances cobalt exposure. Moreover, the Co0/Con+ ratio of Mo/Co-CeO2 (18.5%) is much higher than that of CoMo/CeO2 (10.4%), which is consisted with the conclusion of H2-TPR that there is a higher percent of cobalt metal for Mo/Co-CeO2. Owing to the enhancement of hydrogen spillover from Co species to CeO2 and molybdenum oxides, a rather high proportion of Mo4+ as well as Mo5+ can be found in the Mo 3d spectrum of Mo/Co-CeO2 (Fig. 3b). There is a larger amount of hydrogen consumption in the range from 141 to 328 °C and above 482 °C during H2-TPR study for the oxidized Mo/Co-CeO2 than that of the oxidized CoMo/CeO2 (Fig. S7), further confirming that there is a larger proportion of Co0 and low-valent Mo for the catalyst with the separate addition of cobalt and molybdenum species. There are two O 1 s peak at and 529.5 eV and 531.9 eV for CeO2 (Fig. S6), which can be assigned to lattice oxygen atoms (OL) in a fully coordinated environment and the oxygen atoms in the vicinity of oxygen vacancies (OV) [33,34,56]. The presence of Mo species shifts the peak of OV to lower bonding energy for Mo/CeO2, while the peak position is not change for Co/CeO2 (Fig. S6). Similar change in the position of OV peak can be found in the as-prepared samples or the reduced catalysts (Fig. 3 and S5), further confirming that there is an electronic interaction between molybdenum and oxygen species. That is, oxygen species might withdraw electrons to Mo species for Mo/CeO2, a similar phenomenon observed between nickel and oxygen species [57]. The Ce 3d spectra can be fitted into ten peaks, and the 3d5/2 peaks located at 880.3 eV and 884.8 eV and their corresponding 3d3/2 peaks are ascribed to Ce3+, the remaining six peaks are assigned to the characteristic peaks of tetravalent cerium [33,58]. The Ce3+/Cen+ and OV/OL ratios of Mo/Co-CeO2 are higher than those of CoMo/CeO2, demonstrating that the separate addition of Co and Mo species leads to enhancement of the ceria reducibility, which is in harmony with the results of H2-TPR mentioned before. The depth information in the chemical states of the bimetallic catalysts is further studied by the combination of Ar+ ion etching and XPS analysis. The intensity ratio of Co 2p/Ce 2d (ICo 2p/ICe 3d) almost unchanged when the sputtering time increases from 0 to 60 s (Fig. 4 a), illustrating that cobalt species are uniformly distributed on the surface and the subsurface for these bimetallic catalysts. However, the Co/Ce ratio of Mo/Co-CeO2 is always higher than that of CoMo/CeO2, indicating that the separate introduction of Co and Mo boosts the surface enrichment of Co species. Moreover, the intensity of Co 2p spectra of Co metal greatly increases with the increase of the Ar+ sputtering time (Fig. 5 a and 6a). As a result, it can conclude that there is a higher proportion of Co metal in the subsurface of bimetallic catalysts, especially for Mo/Co-CeO2 (Fig. 4c). As shown in Fig. 4b, the proportion of the exposed Mo species decreases with the increase in the etching time for two samples, but the ratios of Mo 3d to Ce 3d (IMo 3d/ICe 3d) of Mo/Co-CeO2 are always higher than those of CoMo/CeO2. On the other hand, the characteristic peak of Mo4+ also can be observed in CoMo/CeO2 with Ar+ ion etching (Fig. 4b). The Mo 3d5/2 peaks at 228.4 eV corresponding to Mo2+ species can be found in the Mo 3d spectrum of Mo/Co-CeO2 (Fig. 6 b). Therefore, it can conclude that there are higher proportions of the low-valent Mo species and metallic Co in the subsurface of bimetallic catalysts, and the quantities of the low-valent Mo species and Co metal are always higher for Mo/Co-CeO2 than those for CoMo/CeO2 (Fig. 4). The binding energies of the oxygen atoms in the vicinity of oxygen vacancies (OV) shifts to higher values with the increase in Ar+ ion etching time, indicating that a high proportion of the high-valent Mo species contributes to the electron transfer between molybdenum and oxygen species (Fig. 5c and 6c). However, the presence of the low-valent Mo species and Co metal leads to enhancement of CeO2 reducibility, and thus and Ce3+ concentration increase with increasing Ar+ ion etching time (Fig. 5d and 6d). Overall, combining the Raman H2-TPR and XPS results, it can conclude that the exposure of Co species and the reducibility of the catalysts are significantly boosted for the sample separately introduced cobalt and molybdenum in comparison with that added cobalt and molybdenum simultaneously. As a result, Ce3+ concentration, Co and Mo exposure on the surface of catalyst, as well as the proportions of the low-valent Mo species and Co metal all enhance significantly. 3.2 Adsorption property of various catalysts The adsorption properties of the reactants might greatly affect the ammonia synthesis activity of catalyst [25]. As shown in Fig. 7 a, only a broad N2 desorption peak maximum at 602 °C can be observed in the N2-TPD profile of CoMo/CeO2. However, there are two N2 desorption peaks centered at ca. 523 and 812 °C for Mo/Co-CeO2, and the amount of N2 evolution is also larger than that for CoMo/CeO2, demonstrating that introduction of cobalt and molybdenum separately not only facilitates nitrogen desorption, but also enhances the amount of the adsorbed nitrogen. Moreover, the Mo 3p peak of the reduced with N2-H2-Ar mixture shift to high binding energy compared with the sample reduced with H2-Ar mixture (Fig. S8a), indicating that there is an electronic effect between N species and molybdenum species. As shown in Figs. S8b and S9, there is a weak N 1 s peak in XPS spectra of the used catalysts [22,23,59,60], and the ratios of N 1 s peak to Mo 3p peak are 0.009 and 0.019 for the used CoMo/CeO2 and Mo/Co-CeO2, respectively, indicating that a larger amount of nitrogen species existed in the used Mo/Co-CeO2, consistent with the conclusion of N2-TPD. No peaks attributed to Co3Mo3N were observed in the XRD patterns of the used catalysts (Fig. S9), demonstrating that N species remained in the used catalysts might be the nitrides or the adsorbed nitrogen species on the catalyst surface. The amount of hydrogen desorbed during H2-TPD study of Mo/Co-CeO2 is larger than that for CoMo/CeO2 (Fig. 7b), suggesting that the separate addition of Co and Mo species also contributes to hydrogen adsorption and desorption. A D/H exchange experiment was performed to further study the adsorption property of hydrogen. After adsorbing deuterium and purging with argon, the catalysts are exposed in the N2-H2-Ar mixture (Fig. 8 ), and the mass signals of HD and HDO are much stronger than those of D2 and D2O evolution, indicating that D species adsorbed on the bimetallic catalysts would dynamically exchange with the H species from the gaseous phase. Furthermore, the signals of HD and HDO obtained from Mo/Co-CeO2 are stronger than those from CoMo/CeO2, indicating that the deuterium species existed on the surface of Mo/Co-CeO2 is more easily reacted with the gaseous hydrogen. In addition, the resulting H atoms can react with CeO2 to form heterolytic products (Ce − H and OH) or homolytic products (two OH groups) [61,62]. These hydrogen species could desorb in the form of hydrogen molecule or water, which are dependent on the desorption temperature and the number of defect sites [63]. As shown in Fig. S10, there is a larger amount of HD and D2 would be detected below 300 °C for Mo/Co-CeO2 than that for CoMo/CeO2 during the TPSR measurements. In contrast, much stronger m/z = 19 and m/z = 20 signals would be found over CoMo/CeO2 above 350 °C during TPSR measurement. The weak m/z = 16 (NH2 or NHD) and m/z = 17 (NH3 or NH2D) (Fig. S11), reveal that the m/z = 19 and m/z = 20 signals are mainly related to HDO and D2O species. As a result, it can conclude that a larger amount of hydrogen species would preferentially desorb from Mo/Co-CeO2 following the H2-formation pathway, while hydrogen might desorb form CoMo/CeO2 through a water formation pathway. 3.3 Ammonia synthesis performance As shown in Fig. 9 , Mo/Co-CeO2 shows higher catalytic activities than the sample with Co and Mo simultaneous addition (CoMo/CeO2) or the monometallic catalysts (Co/CeO2 and Mo/CeO2) under the same reaction conditions (400 °C, 1 MPa, 180 mL min−1). An increase of weight hourly space velocity from 36 000 to 72 000 mL g−1h−1 results in enhancement of ammonia synthesis rate from 1.3 to 2.7 mmol g−1h−1 for Mo/Co-CeO2, which is comparable to Co–Mo alloy catalyst obtained by sodium naphthalenide-driven reduction (Table S4) [22,23]. Moreover, the ammonia synthesis rates of the bimetallic catalysts increase with the increase of the reaction temperatures, and the activities of Mo/Co-CeO2 are more than 2.5-fold higher than those of CoMo/CeO2 at the studied temperatures, further confirming that the separate addition of Co and Mo species leads to significant enhancement of ammonia synthesis activity. No significant decrease of ammonia synthesis rates is found with the increase of reaction times (Fig. 9c), indicating that these bimetallic catalysts are stable under the adopted conditions. The estimated apparent activation energies are 61 and 57 kJ mol−1 for CoMo/CeO2 and Mo/Co-CeO2, respectively (Fig. S12), which are close to those for Co3Mo3N and the Co–Mo alloy catalyst reported by Tsuji et al (Table S4) [22,23]. As listed in Table S5, the reaction orders of N2 and H2 for Mo/Co-CeO2 are calculated to be 0.69 and 1.09, respectively, which are similar to those for Co-Mo/CeO2 and Co3Mo3N with different Co:Mo ratio [22,23]. These results indicate that the difference in Mo and Co additions slightly affects the reaction mechanism for ammonia synthesis. However, the increase in reaction pressure leads to more significant enhancement of the ammonia synthesis activity for Mo/Co-CeO2 in comparison with CoMo/CeO2, suggesting that the separate introduction of cobalt and molybdenum can alleviate the ill influence of hydrogen poisoning [25,37]. 4 Discussion As mentioned above, the difference in Mo and Co addition strongly affects the properties of the bimetallic catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 10 , Mo species enriched in the surface of the bimetallic catalyst with the simultaneous addition of Co and Mo species (CoMo/CeO2), and the crystalline MoO3 can be found. On the contrary, Co or Mo species both are highly dispersed over CeO2 surface of the bimetallic catalyst with the separate addition of Co and Mo species (Mo/Co-CeO2). Moreover, the addition of Co promotes surface CeO2 reduction, but the presence of molybdenum oxides would inhibit the reduction of cobalt oxides for CoMo/CeO2 (Fig. 2), which might be due to the change in the hydrogen spillover. A color change of WO3 experiment was carried out to further confirm the hydrogen spillover phenomenon in various samples [64,65]. The color change of the mixture Co/CeO2 and WO3 varies from pale yellow to dark blue in a short time, further confirming that there is a fast hydrogen spillover for Co/CeO2 (Fig. S13). In contrast, the slower color change is observed in the mixture CoMo/CeO2 and WO3, indicating that the migration of hydrogen species is inhibited for CoMo/CeO2. The high-valent Mo species can be used as sites for hydrogen evolving in cobalt-molybdenum oxide [4], and then the H species might be rapidly removed from the CoMo/CeO2 surface, leading to a negative impact on the reduction of cobalt oxides, consistent with the H2-TPR results (Fig. 2). On the other hand, the separate introduction of Co and Mo species could reduce the amount of Co species directly contacted with molybdenum oxides. In such a case, the ill effect of molybdenum oxides on the reduction of cobalt oxides can be effectively alleviated, and thus the presence of a larger amount of Co metal leads to enhancement of hydrogen adsorption and faster hydrogen spillover. This conclusion is also confirmed by the faster color change for the mixture of the Mo/Co-CeO2 and WO3 nanowires compared to that for CoMo/CeO2 (Fig. S13). Moreover, it has been found that cobalt species agglomerates on the support surface because of the weak metal-support interaction during hydrogen reduction at low temperature (500 °C) [66]. In the same way, Mo/Co-CeO2 would show higher Co/Ce and Co0/Con+ ratios than CoMo/CeO2, leading to enhancement of the amount of hydrogen desorbed at low temperature (Fig. S14) because Co species is responsible for the activation, adsorption and spillover of hydrogen species for the bimetallic catalysts. Accordingly, the reduction of molybdenum oxides and CeO2 also would be boosted, and thus a larger amount of Ce3+ concentration and low-valent Mo species can be found on the bimetallic catalyst with the separate addition of Co and Mo species (Mo/Co-CeO2). It has been proposed that the strong adsorption of nitrogen on Mo metal results in an inferior ammonia synthesis activity for the Mo-based catalysts, and the presence of ternary nitride Co3Mo3N might be necessary for the development of the efficient Mo catalysts [17]. However, as shown in Fig. S15, Mo species can act as the active sites for nitrogen activation, and the amount of N2 desorbed at low-temperature increases with the increase of Mo loading. XRD result shows that N species remained in the used catalysts might be the nitrides or the adsorbed nitrogen species on the catalyst surface (Fig. S8), and the presence of a larger amount of the low-valent Mo species is also good for nitrogen adsorption and desorption for Mo/Co-CeO2. On the other hand, H2 molecules favor heterolytic dissociation on ceria with abundant Ce3+ species to produce hydride species (Fig. S10), which would desorb in the form of H2 molecules with the rise of temperature [61,62,67,68]. As the result observed over ceria-supported Ru catalysts [58,68,69], the presence of a larger amount of hydrogen species, which more easily desorb following the H2 formation pathway, is advantageous to ammonia synthesis. As a result, Mo/Co-CeO2 shows higher ammonia synthesis activity than CoMo/CeO2. 5 Conclusions In summary, two ceria-supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts with different metal dispersion, reduction degree of ceria and metals and metal-support interactions were prepared by changing Mo addition. The presence of Co metal is good for the reduction of ceria and molybdenum oxide, whereas the reduction of thebimetalliccatalyst would be inhibited by the aggregation of molybdenum oxide for the sample with Co and Mo simultaneous addition. The separate introduction of Co and Mo species can effectively alleviate the ill effect of molybdenum oxide on the reduction of thebimetalliccatalyst, leading to enhancement of the proportion of Co metal as well as surface enrichment of Co species. As a result, the activation and spillover of hydrogen species would be accelerated, and thus there are higher proportions of Ce3+ and low-valent Mo species. The presence of a larger amount of the low-valent Mo species and Co metal contributes to nitrogen/hydrogen adsorption and desorption, and abundant Ce3+ species results in desorption of hydrogen species following a pathway of H2 formation, rather than water formation. As a result, the bimetallic catalyst separately added Co and Mo shows more than 2.5-fold higher activity than that with the simultaneous addition of Co and Mo species. Our study illustrates that the surface segregation behavior and the reduction behavior of active metals play essential roles in the synergistic effect of bimetallic catalyst systems, leading to the variation of reaction gas adsorption and catalytic performances. These findings are important for the design of the reducible oxide-supported bimetallic and multi-component catalysts in sustainable ammonia synthesis or other hydrogen-involved reactions. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient oxides-supported bimetallic catalysts is critical for ammonia synthesis or other catalytic reactions. Herein, the design of ceria-supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts with different properties is performed by changing Mo addition to enhance the ammonia synthesis activities. It is found that the reduction of ceria and molybdenum oxide would be boosted by Co species, but the reduction of the bimetallic catalyst would be inhibited by the aggregated molybdenum oxide for the catalyst with Co and Mo simultaneous addition. On the contrary, this ill effect of molybdenum oxide on the reduction of the bimetallic catalyst can be effectively alleviated by the subsequent addition of Mo species to ceria-supported Co catalyst, resulting in enhancement of the proportion of Co metal, Ce3+ and low-valent Mo species, as well as surface enrichment of Co species. In such cases, the amount of the adsorbed hydrogen and nitrogen species would increase, and hydrogen species preferentially desorbs following a pathway of H2 formation. As a result, the catalyst obtained by the separate addition of Co and Mo shows 2.5-fold more active than its counterpart with the simultaneous addition of Co and Mo species. These findings provide a valuable insight in designing reducible oxide-supported bimetallic catalysts in ammonia synthesis or other hydrogen-involved reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Activity enhancement of ceria-supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts by tuning reducibility and metal enrichment
